channel.title: Comments on: Joy Division/New Order song surfaces in Absolut ad

item.title: By: Matthew
item.dc:creator: Matthew
item.description:
Defintely not the New Order or Joy Division versions of Ceremony - obviously a bit of an instrumental they got some bland band-for-hire to do for the ad.
I don't blame Barney for redoing "Blue Monday" for a Sunkist advert so New Order could get 300 grand. After reading Hooky's book about the Hacienda and the amount of money they tipped into that, that's a group that certainly deserved a few big paydays.
item.content:encoded:
Defintely not the New Order or Joy Division versions of Ceremony – obviously a bit of an instrumental they got some bland band-for-hire to do for the ad.

I don’t blame Barney for redoing “Blue Monday” for a Sunkist advert so New Order could get 300 grand. After reading Hooky’s book about the Hacienda and the amount of money they tipped into that, that’s a group that certainly deserved a few big paydays.

item.title: By: Scott
item.dc:creator: Scott
item.description: Bernard himself sold out and re-did "Blue Monday" for a Sunkist advert. Then again, the group were being paid 300 grand for it. As long as the money's OK, I don't think any of them are complaining.
item.content:encoded: Bernard himself sold out and re-did “Blue Monday” for a Sunkist advert. Then again, the group were being paid 300 grand for it. As long as the money’s OK, I don’t think any of them are complaining.

item.title: By: Mike S
item.dc:creator: Mike S
item.description: If it had to be done, best it were done to promote alcohol rather than a Ford Taurus.
item.content:encoded: If it had to be done, best it were done to promote alcohol rather than a Ford Taurus.

item.title: By: Matt O
item.dc:creator: Matt O
item.description: Ceremony is a sacred song, how dare they just trash its legacy to sell bottles of fucking Vodka. All about the love of music? Don't be so naive, if the company who produced this travesty only wanted to share a love of music, why even mention their product?. If you need advertisements to help you remember a feeling,song or period of time, you really are isolated from the real world, and probably felt little when you hear this song as done by JD, New Order or even the Radiohead version. Anything good that is created as music, art or expression, is eventually ruined, re-manufactured and commercialised by corporations with the time and money. As another poster said, so very sad.
item.content:encoded: Ceremony is a sacred song, how dare they just trash its legacy to sell bottles of fucking Vodka. All about the love of music? Don’t be so naive, if the company who produced this travesty only wanted to share a love of music, why even mention their product?. If you need advertisements to help you remember a feeling,song or period of time, you really are isolated from the real world, and probably felt little when you hear this song as done by JD, New Order or even the Radiohead version. Anything good that is created as music, art or expression, is eventually ruined, re-manufactured and commercialised by corporations with the time and money. As another poster said, so very sad.

item.title: By: Fishy
item.dc:creator: Fishy
item.description: Hate it when they hi-jack ones loved songs. Bad vodka! And it is difinitely not a JD-version.
item.content:encoded:
Hate it when they hi-jack ones loved songs. Bad vodka!
And it is difinitely not a JD-version.

item.title: By: jen
item.dc:creator: jen
item.description: what a God send! I'm ever so grateful for Joy Division/ New Order to be brought back into my heart & soul. Though Ian Curtis may not have wanted his music commercialized, because it was all about the love of his music, this IS all about the love of his music. Without it I wouldn't have recently seen their documentary or movie "Cobtrol", these, as was Joy Division's music ate true gifts.
item.content:encoded: what a God send! I’m ever so grateful for Joy Division/ New Order to be brought back into my heart & soul. Though Ian Curtis may not have wanted his music commercialized, because it was all about the love of his music, this IS all about the love of his music. Without it I wouldn’t have recently seen their documentary or movie “Cobtrol”, these, as was Joy Division’s music ate true gifts.
